newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: INTERVIEW-Sage Group has strong start to H1.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW-Sage Group has strong start to H1.

text.p: Insurance and unit trust investment group Sage Group Ltd has begun its first half in top gear with a rebound in premium growth and continued explosive investments in its unit trusts, its executives said on Tuesday.

"There's no reason to say the present (earnings) trend wouldn't be maintained," chief executive Bruce Ilsley told Reuters after the company unveiled a 25.4 percent leap in headline earnings for the year.
The group posted diluted headline earnings per share of 132.7 cents for the year to March 31, up from 105.8 cents a year ago and exceeding the average analysts' forecast of 132 cents.
The results took Sage's compound annual EPS growth to 23.3 percent over the last five years.
Sage Life managing director Janssen Davies said the division's insurance premium growth had perked up this year.
"This calendar year there's been a pickup again in recurring premiums, whereas last year it was quite depressed. It feels good," he said.
Ilsley said the South African insurance market overall was looking rosy.
"It seems to be that...there's a little more money to invest in life insurance," he added.
New sales in the unit trust division, which roared up 284.5 percent in 1996/97, continued to boom.
"Unit trust sales went from 187 million to 720 million rand and that trend is continuing as we're seeing very good inflows of new money every month," Davies said.

Ilsley said the group was unlikely to come to the market for extra funds following its planned US$40 million to US$50 million preference share issue in Europe which will fund the expansion of its recently-acquired U.S. life insurance unit.
He added the company was focussing on the search for a partner to help expand the U.S. arm which aimed to open for business in the first quarter of 1998.
"The next step overseas would be to take on a strategic partner and that partner would provide at least some of the money required as well."
Ilsley said the company was in discussions with potential partners but was yet to draw up a shortlist.
He said the ideal partner would have a strong rating, a solid image in the U.S. market and be able to add value to Sage's products, especially via distribution.
Sage USA chief executive Ron Scowby said candidates would need an 'A' rating or better from insurance rating agency A.M. Best.
